I said it yesterday and I'll say it again today. An American retreat only emboldens ISIS. This is one example of the terrible consequences of pulling out of Syria, and there'll surely be more to come.   https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/12/21/world/europe/21reuters-mideast-crisis-is-attacks.html …

An American retreat from Syria emboldens ISIS. An American retreat from Afghanistan emboldens Al-Qaeda and undermines the ultimate sacrifice already paid by thousands of Americans. Both will threaten our Homeland again.

A massive retreat of our global leadership only emboldens the mass murderers and oppressors around the world.  If we don’t stand up, who will? https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-administration-is-considering-substantial-afghan-troop-drawdown-11545341452 …

I slept better at night knowing that General Mattis was protecting our nation, our allies, and our brave men and women in uniform – many of whom I’ve worked with in the trenches. This is bad news for the nation and the security of the world. https://www.cbsnews.com/news/james-mattis-resigns-as-defense-secretary-today-12-20-2018/ …
The American people sent us up here to get things done, and the only way we can get things done is by working together. pic.twitter.com/yVWhP5vVra

Cyber attribution is a cyber deterrent. I applaud @TheJusticeDept and @FBI for their investigation and indictment, and I also thank @FBISanAntonio in my hometown for their important role in this investigation.

This shows the importance of continuing bipartisan, bicameral work to improve our government's ability to defend our digital infrastructure through the #MGTact, #FITARA, empowering a Federal CIO and the SECURE Technology Act (which passed the House and Senate last night).
China's objectives are clear: using hacking to steal advanced technology and bolster its position at the expense of other nations.

China methodically siphoned out an immeasurable amount of intellectual property, undermining years of research and development and doing irreparable harm to over 40 companies and government agencies like @NASA and the @USNavy.

This Chinese state-sponsored cyber attack was pervasive, infiltrating systems in the U.S. and around the globe for over four years. We are in a hot war with China, and cyber space is the battle space. https://hurd.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/hurd-statement-significant-chinese-cyber-aggression …

We have to look at what our allies and enemies think. The fact that Russia, Iran, and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad all support this decision to remove U.S. troops from Syria is a problem. We cannot allow ISIS to regroup, train, equip and run operations unencumbered. pic.twitter.com/GS6QZ8qcGI

Public libraries, especially in rural areas, do much more than simply offer books. They’re often the main provider of literacy programming, tech training & job seeking assistance in many #TX23 communities. Glad my colleagues came together to support our bipartisan bill today https://twitter.com/ALALibrary/status/1075559462050693120 …

We cannot abandon our allies, like the Syrian Democratic Forces, and create an opening for ISIS, Iran and Russia to determine the fate of millions of Syrians and create a safe haven for terrorist groups that threaten our security.
ISIS is a global threat and could re-emerge as a destructive insurgency in Syria and Iraq.

Withdrawing our ground forces undermines the strong, global coalition we built to defeat this threat. It is clear from available intelligence that ISIS is trying to rebuild and still commands a significant fighting force of over 30k.

Earlier this month, the US-led coalition to defeat ISIS was undertaking new operations in Eastern Syria. And last week the Chairman of Joint Chiefs said we’ve only trained 20% of the forces necessary to stabilize areas formerly held by ISIS.

.@RepKinzinger is right. This decision undercuts the chance of completely defeating ISIS and instead bolsters the Assad regime, which has gassed its own people, killed hundreds of thousands and caused over 6M refugees. https://twitter.com/RepKinzinger/status/1075390831945809920 …

We're better than this. This is a symptom of a larger problem we’ve spent years ignoring – our broken immigration system. And similar to building a wall from sea to shining sea, detaining kids in Tornillo is the most expensive and least effective way to solve anything. pic.twitter.com/SFOUbIXZRQ

I’m glad new leadership at @HHSGov tweaked this policy that created the need for unnecessary facilities like in Tornillo. We can place children in a safe environment and reduce the administrative hurdles to close the Tornillo facility by the new year. https://www.texasmonthly.com/news/trump-fingerprint-policy-change-reduce-migrant-children-detention-tornillo/ …
We are the United States of America… we are better than this.
.@HHSGov then work with the home governments of the remaining 400 kids to find a family member in their home country.
.@HHSGov then speed up the processing for the 1100 kids who have sponsors but are waiting to schedule fingerprinting.
.@HHSGov stop intentionally delaying the release of 1300 kids to family members who have already submitted finger prints.
Just got off the phone with management at Tornillo tent facility. Contract set to end Dec 31 but @HHSGov has no plan for 2800 kids.
